questions.question: A newspaper in a town is published every day. One copy has 24 pages. Everyday 85,000 copies are printed. On Sundays 15000 more copies are printed. How many total pages are printed on Sundays?
questions.examples:
Example 1. A magazine is published every month. One copy has 90 pages. Every month 50,000 copies are printed. The anniversary publication happens in the month of December every year. 5000 more copies are printed in December. How many total pages are printed in December?

Soln.
In the month of December 55,000 (50000+5000) copies are printed.
Each copy is 90 pages.
So the number of pages = 55000 * 90 = 49,50,000

Example 2. A film magazine is printed every fortnight. Each copy has 60 pages. Every fortnight 30000 copies are printed. They bring out an anniversary issue during the first fortnight of every new year. They print an additional 5000 copies during the anniversary sale. How many pages are printed during the anniversary sale?
Soln.
Number of copies printed during anniversary sale are (30000+5000) =35000
Each copy has 60 pages
So number of pages printed during anniversary sale are 35000*60 = 21,00,000

questions.question: 20% of a number is 60. What is 15% of the same number?
questions.examples:
Example 1. 40% of a number is 120. What is 20% of the same number?

Soln : Let the number be x
40/100 * x = 120
x = 300
So 20% of the same number = 20/100 * 300 = 60

Example 2. 30% of a number is 90. What is 45% of the same number?

Soln : Let the number be x
30/100 * x = 90
x = 300
So 45% of the same number = 45/100 * 300 = 135

questions.question: By selling a watch for Rs 960, a profit of 20% is made. What is the gain or loss percentage if it is sold for Rs 760.
questions.examples:
Example 1
Sridhar buys an old scooter for Rs. 4700 and spends Rs. 800 on its repairs. If he sells the scooter for Rs. 5800, what is his gain percent?
Soln :
Cost Price (CP) = 4700 + 800 = Rs. 5500.

Selling Price (SP) = Rs. 5800.

Gain = (SP) - (CP) = 5800 - 5500= Rs. 300.
Gain%=(Gain/CP)×100=(300/5500)×100=300/55=60/11=5 5/11

Example 2
A man buys a scooter for Rs. 14000 and sells it at a loss of 15%. What is the selling price of the scooter?
SP=14000×85/100=140×85=11900

questions.question: A, B and C invested Rs 64000, Rs 72000 and Rs 92000 respectively to carry on a business. What is the share of C in the annual profit of Rs 11400?
questions.examples:
Example 1: Raj invested Rs 70000 in a business. Murali invested Rs 50000 .
What is the share of Murali in the annual profit of Rs 18000?


Solution – Ratio of investments = 70000 : 50000 = 7:5

Annual profit = 18000

As per the investments made, Murali will get 5 parts out of total parts of 12(7+5).

Hence in 18000, he will get 18000 * 5/12 = 7500

Example 2: Sumit and Ravi started a business by investing Rs 85000 and 15000 respectively. In what ratio the profit earned after 2 years be divided between Sumit and Ravi respectively.

Soln :

P:Q = 85000:15000 = 17:3

Important to note there that if both have invested for different period of times then we had to multiply with number of months to get the desired ratio.

questions.question: Find the difference between the greatest and the least number that can be written using the digits 6, 0, 7, 4, 3 each only once.
questions.examples:
Example 1. Form the greatest and the smallest number using the digits 6, 3, 8, 7, 1

Solution:
Tth Th H T U
8 7 6 3 1 So, greatest number = 87631
1 3 6 7 8 So, smallest number = 13678

We may say the procedure of forming the greatest number is as follows:

(a) The smallest digit is placed at one’s place.

(b) The next greater digit is placed at ten's place.

(c) The next greater digit is placed at hundred's place and so on.

(d) The greatest digit is placed at the highest place of the number.


The smallest number is formed by the following the reverse procedure.

(a) The greatest digit is placed at one's place.

(b) The next smaller digit at ten’s place and so on till all the given digits are finished.
(c) The smallest digit is placed at the highest place of the number.

Example 2. Write the greatest and smallest number with the given 5 digits (2, 0, 5, 3, 9) without repeating any digit.
Solution:
Tth Th H T O
Greatest number 9 5 3 2 0 So, greatest number = 95320
Smallest number 2 0 3 5 9 So, smallest number = 20359

(Whenever one of the given digits is 0, it is not written at the extreme left for the smallest number. It is written in the second place from the left)

questions.question: The sum of three consecutive even numbers is 90. What is the middle number ?
questions.examples:
Example 1: Sum of three consecutive even integers, whose sum is 264. Find the middle number
Soln
Let the first even integer be X
X+(X+2)+(X+4)=264
3X+6=264
3X=264-6
3X=258
X=258/3
X=86
Hence 86+2=88 is the middle number.

questions.question: A house wife has savings of Rs 25000 with her. She placed an order for purchasing 4 chairs costing Rs 4500 each and a table costing Rs 5500. How much money will remain with her after the purchase?
questions.examples:
Example 1
A house wife has savings of Rs 15000 with her. She placed an order for purchasing 2 chairs costing Rs 3500 each and a table costing Rs 5000. How much money will remain with her after the purchase?
Soln
Purchase cost of each chair Rs 3500
Hence two chairs cost Rs 3500 * 2 = 7000
Purchase cost of table Rs 5000
Expense incurred so far Rs 7000+5000 = 12000
Savings with her = 15000
So money remaining after the purchase = Rs 15000-12000=3000

Example 2
A student has a savings of Rs 1000. She intends to purchase three note books costing Rs 150 each and a bag costing Rs 500. How much money is left with her?
Cost of each note book = Rs 150
Cost of three note books = 150*3=450
Cost of bag = Rs 500
Total cost of bag and 3 note books = Rs 500+450 = 950
Money left with her = Rs 1000-950= Rs 50

questions.question: Determine the smallest 3-digit number which is exactly divisible by 5, 10 and 15.
questions.examples:
Example 1 which is the smallest 3 digit number which is exactly divisible by 6,8, 12

The lowest common factor would be

We need to find the common factor greater than 99.
Multiplying 24 by 4 would only reach 96.
Hence Multiply by 5.

So the smallest three digit number which is exactly divisible by 6, 8, 12 is 120.


Example 2
Find the least 5 digit number which is exactly divisible by 20,25,30?

LCM of 20,25,30 is 300.

300 is only a 3-digit number, and all multiples of 300 are divisible by 20, 25 and 30. We want a least 5-digit number.

We divide 10000 which is the least 5 digit number by 300 and get 33.33333...

So the smallest integer greater than that is 34.

So our number = 300*34 or 10200.

questions.question: Determine the greatest 3-digit number exactly divisible by 10, 20 and 30.
questions.examples:
Example 1: What is the greatest number of four digits which is divisible by 15, 25, 40 and 75 ?
Soln:
Greatest number of four digits = 9999

LCM of 15, 25, 40 and 75 = 600

9999 ÷ 600 = 16, remainder = 399

Hence, greatest number of four digits which is divisible by 15, 25, 40 and 75

= 9999 - 399 = 9600

Example 2
Find the largest number of four digits which is exactly divisible by 27,18,12,15

Solution:
LCM of 27-18-12-15 is 540.
After dividing 9999 by 540 we get 279 remainder.
So answer will be 9999-279 = 9720

questions.question: A person had to multiply two numbers. Instead of multiplying by 35, he multiplied by 53 and the product went up by 540. What was the raised product?
questions.examples:
A person had to multiply two numbers. Instead of multiplying by 34, he multiplied by 43 and the product went up by 450. What was the raised product?
Let x be the first number.
If multiplied by 34. Product = 34x
If multiplied by 43. Product = 43x
Difference :
43x-34x = 450
9x = 450. So x = 50
The raised product = 50*43 = 2150

Example 2
A person had to multiply two numbers. Instead of multiplying by 45, he multiplied by 54 and the product went up by 540. What was the raised product?
Let x be the first number.
If multiplied by 45. Product = 45x
If multiplied by 54. Product = 54x
Difference :
54x-45x = 540
9x = 540. So x = 60
The raised product = 60*54 = 3240

questions.question: A box of 100 packets consists of 1kg packets and 2kg packets. Total weight of box is 160kg. How many 2kg packets are present in the box ?
questions.examples:
Example 1
Two small pitchers and one large pitcher can hold 8 cups of water. One large pitcher minus one small pitcher constitutes 2 cups of water. How many cups of water can each pitcher hold?
Soln :
Let x = small pitcher
y = large pitcher

2x + y = 8
y - x = 2
Solve by any method .
If done algebraically:
2x + y = 8
-x + y = 2
subtract:
3x = 6
x = 2
The small pitcher holds 2 cups of water.
2(2) + y = 8
4 + y = 8
y = 4
The large pitcher holds 4 cups of water.

Example 2
A test has twenty questions worth 100 points. The test consists of True/False questions worth 3 points each and multiple choice questions worth 11 points each. How many multiple choice questions are on the test?
Let x = T/F questions
Let y = Multiple Choice questions
x + y = 20
3x + 11y = 100
Solve by any method.
If done algebraically:
x + y = 20
3x + 11y = 100
3(x + y = 20)
3x + 11 y = 100
3x + 3y = 60
3x + 11y = 100
-8y = -40
8y = 40
y = 5
There are 5 multiple choice questions.
x + 5 = 20
x = 15
There are 15 T/F questions.

questions.question: With 3/4th full tank, a vehicle travels 18 miles. How much distance is travelled with 1/3rd full tank?
questions.examples:
Example 1
With four fifths of the tank full, a vehicle travels 12 miles. How much distance will the vehicle travel with one third tank full?

4/5th of full tank = 80% of full tank, a vehicle travels 12 miles
So with 100% of full tank, a vehicle travels (12*100)/80 = 15 miles
Hence with 1/3rd of full tank, it will travel = (1/3)*15 = 5 miles
Example 2.
With 3/4th full tank, a vehicle travels 36 miles. How much distance is travelled with 1/2 (half) tank of fuel in it?
75% of full tank covers a distance of 36 miles.
100% of full tank covers a distance of (100*36)/75 = 48 miles
So half of fuel tank i.e 50% of fuel tank covers a distance of 48/2 which is equal to 24 miles.

questions.question: Wind blows 160 miles in 190 min. For 80 miles how much time is required?
questions.examples:
Example 1
Wind blows 160 miles in 330min.for 80 miles how much time required
Soln

160/330=80/t,

t=80*330/160=165 minutes

Example 2
Wind blows 180 miles in 360min. For 90 miles how much time required

180 miles= 360 min
1 mile = 360/180
90 miles=(360*90)/180=180 min.

questions.question: A person was fined for exceeding the speed limit by 10mph. Another person was also fined for exceeding the same speed limit by twice the amount. If the second person was travelling at a speed of 35 mph, find the speed limit.
questions.examples:
Example 1
A person was fined for exceeding the speed limit by 10mph. Another person was also fined for exceeding the same speed limit by thrice the amount. If the second person was travelling at a speed of 70 mph, find the speed limit.
Let the speed limit be x mph
First person was fined for exceeding the speed limit by 10 mph. It means he is travelling at x+10 mph
Second person was fined thrice for exceeding the speed limit. It means he is travelling x+10+10+10 mph
It is also stated that second person is travelling at 70 mph
So x+10+10+10 = 70
X+30=70
X = 70-30 = 40 mph

Example 2
A person was fined for exceeding the speed limit by 10mph. Another person was also fined for exceeding the same speed limit by twice the amount. If the second person was travelling at a speed of 60 mph, find the speed limit.
Let the speed limit be x mph
First person was fined for exceeding the speed limit by 10 mph. It means he is travelling at x+10 mph
Second person was fined twice for exceeding the speed limit. It means he is travelling x+10+10 mph
It is also stated that second person is travelling at 60 mph
So x+10+10 = 60
X+20=60
X = 60-20 = 40 mph

questions.question: A person who decided to go weekend trip should not exceed 8 hours driving in a day. Average speed of forward journey is 40kmph and return journeyaverage speed is 60 kmph. How far can he select a picnic spot?
questions.examples:
Example 1
While going to a place a person travels 50 kmph and returns at 30 kmph. Find his average speed?
Average speed is given by the formula = 2xy/(x+y)
So Avg speed = 2*50*30/(50+30) = 37.5 kmph

Example 2
While going to a place a person travels 80 kmph during first half of the journey and travels at 60 kmph during the second half of the journey. Find his average speed? How much distance will he be able cover in 7 hours.
Average speed = 2xy/(x+y)
= 2 *80*60/(80+60) = 480/7
In 7 hours the distance covered = Avg speed * time = 480/7*7 = 480 kms.

questions.question: A bike is filled with four and half litres of petrol for full round trip. Fuel consumed in going is 1/4 times more than the fuel consumed in coming. What is the fuel consumed in coming?
questions.examples:
Example 1
Example: Sam and Alex play Tennis. On the weekend Sam played 4 more games than Alex did, and together they played 12 games. How many games did Alex play?
Turn the English into Algebra:
Letters:
Use S for how many games Sam played
Use A for how many games Alex played
We know that Sam played 4 more games than Alex, so: S=A + 4
And we know that together they played 12 games: S + A = 12
We are being asked for how many games Alex played: A
Solve:
Start with: S + A = 12
S = A + 4, so we can
substitute "A+4" for S: (A + 4) + A = 12
Simplify: 2A + 4 = 12
Subtract 4 from both sides: 2A = 12 - 4
Simplify: 2A = 8
Divide both sides by 2: A = 4
Which means that Alex played 4 games of tennis.
Check: Sam played 4 more games than Alex, so Sam played 8 games. Together they played 8 + 4 = 12 games. Yes!
Example 2:
Alex and Sam also build tables.
Together they make 10 tables in 12 days.
Alex working alone can make 10 in 30 days.
How long would it take Sam working alone to make 10 tables?
Turn the English into Algebra:
Letters:
Use a for Alex's work rate
Use s for Sam's work rate
12 days of Alex and Sam is 10 tables, so: 12a + 12s = 10
30 days of Alex alone is also 10 tables: 30a = 10
We are being asked how long it would take Sam to make 10 tables.
Solve:
30a = 10, so Alex's rate (tables per day) is: a = 10/30 = 1/3
Start with: 12a + 12s = 10
Put "1/3" for a: 12(1/3) + 12s = 10
Simplify: 4 + 12s = 10
Subtract 4 from both sides: 12s = 6
Divide both sides by 12: s = 6/12
Simplify: s = 1/2
Which means that Sam's rate is half a table a day (faster than Alex!)
So 10 tables would take Sam just 20 days.

B's 10 day's work = 1 x 10 = 2 .
15 3

18

Worker A takes 8 hours to do a job. Worker B takes 10 hours to do a job. How long should it take both A and B, working together to do same job.

In this type of questions, first we need to calculate 1 hours work, then their collective work as,

A's 1 hour work is 1/8
B's 1 hour work is 1/10

(A+B)'s 1 hour work = 1/8 + 1/10
= 9/40

So both will finish the work in 40/9 hours
=
(4 4/9)

questions.question: A cricket batsmanâ€™s average in first 25 innings was 25. After the 26th innings his average was 26 how many runs he scored in the 26th innings?
questions.examples:
Example 1
A cricket batsmanâ€™s average in first 21 innings was 21. After the 26th innings his average was 23 how many runs he scored in the 23th innings?
Sol:
Average of 21 innings= (sum/21)=21
Sum= 21*21
Let the score of his 23rd inning= x
Average after 23 innings= (sum + x) / 23 = 23
X= (23*23)-(21*21)
X=88
Example 2:
The average age of a class of 30 students and a teacher reduces by 0.5 years if we exclude the teacher. If the initial average is 14 years, find the age of the class teacher?
Sol:
Age of teacher= Total age of (students + Teacher) â€“ Total age of students
=(31 X 14) â€“ (30 X 13.5)=434 â€“ 405 = 29 years

questions.question: When 8 is subtracted out from two third of X, the result is 25 more than one third of X. Find X.
questions.examples:
Example 1
When 7 is subtracted out from two third of X, the result is 21 more than one third of X. Find X.
Sol: (2X/3)-7= 21+ (X/3)
(X/3) = 28
X= 84
Example 2:
One-fourth of sum of a number and 5 is 1/3rd of the same number. What is the number ?
Solution:
Based on the question statement, we can form the below equation.
(1/4) x (p+5) = 1/3 x p
3 x (p+5) = 4p
3p + 15 = 4p
4p â€“ 3p = 15
p = 15

(p/2)-(p/5)=1
3p/10 = 1
P= 10/3
Example 2:
8 reduced from 1/6 of a number is 9 reduced from half of the same number. Find the number
Sol:
(p X 1)/6 â€“ 8 = (p/2) â€“ 9
(p/2)-(p/6)=1
4p/12 = 1
P= 3

questions.question: Anil is twice as fast as Mohith. Mohith is thrice as fast as Annie. The distance covered by Annie in 54 minutes will be covered by Mohith in ___ minutes
questions.examples:
Example 1:
Anitha is thrice as fast as Mrudula. Mrudula is twice as fast as Raju. The distance covered by Raju in 48 minutes will be covered by Mrudula in ___ minutes
Sol:
As speed is inversely proportional to time,
(Speed of Raju/Speed of Mrudula) = (Time taken by Mrudula/Time taken by Raju)
(1/2 X Speed of Mrudula )/ Speed of Mrudula = (Time taken by Mrudula/48)
Time taken by Mrudula = 48/2 = 24 minutes
Example 2:
Rishi is thrice as fast as Manasa. Manasa is thrice as fast as Rakesh. The distance covered by Rakesh in 63 minutes will be covered by Manasa in ___ minutes
Sol:
As speed is inversely proportional to time,
(Speed of Rakesh/Speed of Manasa) = (Time taken by Manasa/Time taken by Rakesh)
(1/3 X Speed of Manasa )/ Speed of Manasa = (Time taken by Manasa /63)
Time taken by Manasa = 63/3 = 21 minutes

questions.question: At the time of his marriage Arunachalam was 29 years old. During marriage, his wife was younger by 3 Â½ years. 20 years afterwards the total ages of Arunachalam, his wife and their only son Kamalraj is 110 years. What is the age of Kamalraj now?
questions.examples:
When Arunraj joined Engineering College Bobbiliraj was 34 months old. Sunilrajâ€™s (father of Arunraj) age was two months less than 14 times the age of Bobbiliraj. Arunrajâ€™s age was six months more than six times the age of Bobbiliraj.
Now, Bobbiliraj has attained the age of Arunraj when he (Arunraj) joined the Engineering College. What will be the total age of all the three â€“ Bobbiliraj, Arunraj and Sunilraj now?
Solution :
Part I : Calculation of Ages During Arunraj's Joining In Engineering College
Age of Bobbiliraj = 34 months
Sunilraj's age = 14 x Bobbiliraj's age - 2 = 14 x 34 - 2 = 474 months
Arunraj's age = 6 x Bobbiliraj's age + 6 = 6 x 34 + 6 = 210 months
Part II : Calculation of Current Ages
Bobbiliraj's current age = Age of Arunraj when he (Arunraj) joined college = 210 months
Months elapsed between present time and time when Arunraj joined college = Present age of Bobbiliraj - Age of Bobbiliraj when Arunraj joined college = 210 - 34 = 176 months
Current ages of Sunilraj and Arunraj can be found by adding the time elapsed (176 months) to their previously calculated ages.
Therefore, Sunilraj's current age = 474 + 176 = 650 months
Arunraj's current age = 210 + 176 = 386 months
Total ages of the three = 210 + 650 + 386 = 1246 months = 103 years and 10 months.
Q. Jambu was 60 months old when Padmanabhan joined Infosys. Padmanabhan had joined Infosys 80 months back. Mohanraj is now eighty months more than six times the age of Jambu when Padmanabhan joined Infosys. The total of the ages of Jambu, Padmanabhan and Mohanraj is 100 years after lapse of 8 1/3 years. What was the age at which Padmanabhan joined Infosys?
Solution :
Part I. During Padmanabhan's Joining at Infosys
Jambu's age = 60 months
Part II. Current Ages
Since Padmanabhan had joined 80 month's back, Jambu's current age = Jambu's age when Padmanabhan joined Infosys + 80 = 60 + 80 = 140 months
(According to data in question) Mohanraj's current age = 80 months + 6 x Jambu's age when Padmanabhan joined Infosys = 80 + 6 x 60 = 440 months
Part III. Ages after 8 1/3 years (or 8 years + 1/3 year = 8 x 12 months + 12/3 months = 100 months)
Jambu's age after 100 months = Jambu's current age + 100 months = 140 + 100 = 240 months
Mohanraj's age after 100 months = Mohanraj's current age + 100 months = 440 + 100 = 540 months
If we assume current age of Padmanabhan as P, then his age after 100 months = P + 100
It is given that after 100 months, the sum of the ages is 100 years or 1200 months.
i.e 240 + 540 + P + 100 = 1200
Or P = 320 months
We have to find, Padmanabhan's age when he joined Infosys. i,e we have to find his age before 80 months.
Therefore, our answer = P - 80 = 320 - 80 = 240 months = 240/12 years = 20 years

questions.question: P and Q can do a piece of work in 20 days, Q and R in 24 days, and R and P in 15 days. If all three of them are working, what part of the work is done in one day
questions.examples:
Example 1:
A can finish a work in 18 days and B can do the same work in 15 days. B worked for 10 days and left the job. In how many days, A alone can finish the remaining work?
B's 10 day's work =(1/15)x 10=2/3.
Remaining work =1-(2/3)=1/3
Now,1/18 work is done by A in 1 day.
Therefore 1/3 work is done by A in (18/3)=6 days
Example 2 :
Worker A takes 8 hours to do a job. Worker B takes 10 hours to do a job. How long should it take both A and B, working together to do same job.
Soln:
In this type of questions, first we need to calculate 1 hours work, then their collective work as,

A's 1 hour work is 1/8
B's 1 hour work is 1/10

(A+B)'s 1 hour work = 1/8 + 1/10
= 9/40

So both will finish the work in 40/9 hours
=
(4 4/9)

questions.question: The number ‘X’ is exactly divisible by 5. The remainder after the division of the number ‘Y’ by 5 is equal to 1 and the remainder after the division of the number ‘Z’ by 5 is equal to 2. What is the remainder when the number (2X + 3Y – 4Z) is divided by 5?
questions.examples:
Example 1:
If n is a natural number, then (6n2+6n) is always divisible by:
6n2 + 6n = 6n(n + 1)

Hence 6n2 + 6n is always divisible by 6 and 12 (since remember that n(n + 1) is always even)
Example 2 :
If x and y are positive integers such that (3x + 7y) is a multiple of 11, then which of the following will be divisible by 11 ?
A.
4x + 6y B.
x + y + 4
C.
9x + 4y D.
4x - 9y

Solution:
By hit and trial, we put x = 5 and y = 1 so that (3x + 7y) = (3 x 5 + 7 x 1) = 22, which is divisible by 11.
(4x + 6y) = ( 4 x 5 + 6 x 1) = 26, which is not divisible by 11;
(x + y + 4 ) = (5 + 1 + 4) = 10, which is not divisible by 11;
(9x + 4y) = (9 x 5 + 4 x 1) = 49, which is not divisible by 11;
(4x - 9y) = (4 x 5 - 9 x 1) = 11, which is divisible by 11.

questions.question: The sum of two integers is 10 and the sum of their reciprocals is 5 /12. Then the larger of these integers is
questions.examples:
Example 1:
The sum of two integers is thirty. Eight times the smaller integer is six more than five times the larger integer. Find the integers.
Soln: First of all we must form equations. Now,
Let the smaller integer = x and
Let the greater integer = y
x + y = 30 ...............(1) Given. The sum of the integers
8x = 5y + 6 or } Given. 8 times the smaller integer is
8x - 5y = 6 ...............(2)} bigger by 6 than 5 times the greater
} integer.
(1) * 5, we get,
5x + 5y = 150 .............(3)
By adding Eq.(2) and (3),
13x = 156
So x = 156/13 = 12
By replacing this value of x in Eq.(1), we get
12 + y = 30
So y = 30 - 12 = 18
So, 12 and 18 are the integers.
Example 2:
Twice the larger of two numbers is three more than five times the smaller, and the sum of four times the larger and three times the smaller is 71. What are the numbers?
Solution
Let the larger number: x
Let the smaller number: y

twice the larger: 2x
three more than five times the smaller: 5y + 3
relationship between ("is"): 2x = 5y + 3

four times the larger: 4x
three times the smaller: 3y
relationship between ("sumof"): 4x + 3y = 71

Now I have two equations in two variables:

2x = 5y + 3
4x + 3y = 71

I will solve, say, the first equation for x:

x = (5/2)y + (3/2)

Then I'll plug the right-hand side of this into the second equation in place of the "x":

4[ (5/2)y + (3/2) ] + 3y = 71
10y + 6 + 3y = 71
13y + 6 = 71
13y = 65
y = 65/13 = 5

Now that I have the value for y, I can solve for x:

x = (5/2)y + (3/2)
x = (5/2)(5) + (3/2)
x = (25/2) + (3/2)
x = 28/2 = 14

As always, I need to remember to answer the question that was actually asked. The solution here is not "x = 14", but is the following sentence:

The larger number is 14, and the smaller number is 5.

questions.question: How many times does the digit 6 appear when you count from 11 to 100?
questions.examples:
Example 1:
How many number of times will the digit '7' be written when listing the integers from 1 to 1000?
From :1-100 = 20 ( 7,17,27,37,47,57,67,70-79,87,97 =20 , PS=77 has two 7 digits)
From :101-200 = 20
From :201-300 = 20
From :301-400 = 20
From :401-500 = 20
From :501-600 = 20
From :601-699 = 20
From :700-800 = 20 + 100
From :801-900 = 20
From :901-1000 = 20

Total = 20x10 + 100= 300
Example 2:
How many times number 3 appears in 1 to 1000 ?
Another method of solving :
Any number between 1 and 999 can be expressed in the form of xyz where 0 < x, y, z < 9.

Case 1. The numbers in which 3 occurs only once. This means that 3 is one of the digits and the remaining two digits will be any of the other 9 digits

You have 1*9*9 = 81 such numbers. However, 3 could appear as the first or the second or the third digit. Therefore, there will be 3*81 = 243 numbers (1-digit, 2-digits and 3- digits) in which 3 will appear only once.

Case 2. The numbers in which 3 will appear twice. In these numbers, one of the digits is not 3 and it can be any of the 9 digits.
There will be 9 such numbers. However, this digit which is not 3 can appear in the first or second or the third place. So there are 3 * 9 = 27 such numbers.

In each of these 27 numbers, the digit 3 is written twice. Therefore, 3 is written 54 times.

Case 3. The number in which 3 appears thrice - 333 - 1 number. 3 is written thrice in it.

Therefore, the total number of times the digit 3 is written between 1 and 999 is 243 + 54 + 3 = 300

Ratio of water to milk = [.25x + .5(12-x)] : [.75x + .5(12-x)] = 3 : 5

questions.question: How many prime numbers are less than 50?
questions.examples:
Example 1:
Which of the following pairs are Twin Primes?
A.(19, 21) B.(29, 31) C.(39, 41) D.(49, 51)
Twin Primes are a pair of prime numbers that differ by 2 (successive odd numbers that are both prime numbers).

21 = 3 Ã— 7, so is not prime. So (19, 21) are not Twin Primes.
29 and 31 are both prime numbers, so they are Twin Primes
39 = 3 Ã— 13, so is not prime. So (39, 41) are not Twin Primes.
49 = 7 Ã— 7 and 51 = 3 Ã— 17, so neither number is prime. So (49, 51) are not Twin Primes.

The only pair of Twin primes is (29, 31)
Example 2:
Which of the following pairs of numbers are NOT co-prime?
A. 16 and 25 B. 26 and 35 C. 36 and 45 D.46 and 55
Solution:
Co-prime means they do not have any common factors other than 1 or -1.

16 = 24 and 25 = 52, so 16 and 25 have no common factors (except 1) and are co-prime
26 = 2 Ã— 13 and 35 = 5 Ã— 7, so 26 and 35 have no common factors (except 1) and are co-prime
36 = 22 Ã— 32 and 45 = 5 Ã— 32, so they have a factor 32 in common and are NOT co-prime.
46 = 2 Ã— 23 and 55 = 5 Ã— 11, so 46 and 55 have no common factors (except 1) and are co-prime

When a plot is sold for Rs. 18,700, the owner loses 15%. At what price must that plot be sold in order to gain 15%?
Soln:
85 : 18700 = 115 : x
x = (18700 x 115)/85 = 25300.
Hence, S.P. = Rs. 25,300.

questions.question: Today is Sunday, after 39 days, it will be
questions.examples:
Example 1:
It was Sunday on Jan 1, 2006. What was the day of the week Jan 1, 2010?
Soln:
On 31st December, 2005 it was Saturday.
Number of odd days from the year 2006 to the year 2009 = (1 + 1 + 2 + 1) = 5 days.
On 31st December 2009, it was Thursday.
Thus, on 1st Jan, 2010 it is Friday.
Example 2:
Today is tuesday. After 72 days, it will be ?
Tuesday will be repeated after each 7 days so, after at 70 day it will also be tuesday, so at 72 th day it will be Friday

questions.question: The speed of a boat when travelling downstream is 32 kmph whereas when travelling upstream it is 28 kmph. What is the speed of the boat in still water?
questions.examples:
Example 1:
A man's speed with the current is 15 km/hr and the speed of the current is 2.5 km/hr. The man's speed against the current is:

A. 8.5 km/hr B. 9 km/hr
C. 10 km/hr D. 12.5 km/hr

Solution :
Man's rate in still water = (15 - 2.5) km/hr = 12.5 km/hr.

Man's rate against the current = (12.5 - 2.5) km/hr = 10 km/hr.

Example 2:
In one hour, a boat goes 11 km/hr along the stream and 5 km/hr against the stream. The speed of the boat in still water (in km/hr) is:

A. 3 km/hr B. 5 km/hr
C. 8 km/hr D. 9 km/hr
Solution
Speed in still water = 1/2 * (11 + 5) kmph = 8 kmph

questions.question: In an examination, 40 students passed in Hindi and 20 students passed in Maths. If 15 students passed in both the exams. Find the number of students who appeared in the examination.
questions.examples:
Example 1:
Answer to Question 1
1. In a class of 50 students, 18 take Chorus, 26 take Band, and 2 take both Chorus and Band. How many students in the class are not enrolled in either Chorus or Band?


16 + 2 + 24 + x = 50
42 + x = 50
x = 8 students

Example 2:
In a school of 320 students, 85 students are in the band, 200 students are on sports teams, and 60 students participate in both activities. How many students are involved in either band or sports?

25 + 60 + 140 = 225
There are 225 students involved
in either band or sports.

questions.question: X, Y, Z subscribe Rs. 50,000 for a business. X subscribes Rs. 4000 more than Y and Y Rs. 5000 more than Z. Out of a total profit of Rs. 35,000, X  receives:
questions.examples:
Example 1:
Raj invested Rs 70000 in a business. Murali invested Rs 50000 .
What is the share of Murali in the annual profit of Rs 18000?


Solution â€“ Ratio of investments = 70000 : 50000 = 7:5

Annual profit = 18000

As per the investments made, Murali will get 5 parts out of total parts of 12(7+5).

Hence in 18000, he will get 18000 * 5/12 = 7500

Example 2:
Sumit and Ravi started a business by investing Rs 85000 and 15000 respectively. In what ratio the profit earned after 2 years be divided between Sumit and Ravi respectively.

Soln :

P:Q = 85000:15000 = 17:3

Important to note there that if both have invested for different period of times then we had to multiply with number of months to get the desired ratio.

questions.question: Which of the following can't be the square of a natural number?
questions.examples:
Example 1:

How many two-digit numbers satisfy this property.: The last digit (unit's digit) of the square of the two-digit number is 8 ?
A. 1 B. 2
C. 3 D. None of these
Solution:
A number ending in 8 can never be a perfect square.
Example 2:
A group of students decided to collect as many paise from each member of group as is the number of members. If the total collection amounts to Rs. 98.01, the number of the member is the group is:
A. 101 B. 98
C. 99 D. 88

Solution:
Let the number of members = n

Then n2 = Total amount of money collected = 9801 paise
ie, n= square root on 9801=99

i.e., number of members = 99

questions.question: A pole 15.5 m high casts a shadow of length 40 m. The height of the building, which casts a shadow of length 25 m under similar conditions will be:
questions.examples:
A pole 16 m high casts a shadow of length 40 m. The height of the building, which casts a shadow of length 25 m under similar conditions will be:

A.10 m B. 12.5 m C.17.5 m D.21.5m


Example 1:
If 7 spiders make 7 webs in 7 days, then 1 spider will make 1 web in how many days?
A.
1 B.
7
2

C.
7 D.
49
Solutions:
Let the required number days be x.
Less spiders, More days (Indirect Proportion)
Less webs, Less days (Direct Proportion)
Spiders 1 : 7
:: 7 : x
Webs 7 : 1
hence 1 x 7 x x = 7 x 1 x 7
=> x = 7.
Example 2:
If a quarter kg of potato costs 60 paise, how many paise will 200 gm cost?
A.
48 paise B.
54 paise
C.
56 paise D.
72 paise
Solution:
Let the required weight be x kg.
Less weight, Less cost (Direct Proportion)
250 : 200 :: 60 : x <=> 250 x x = (200 x 60)
=> x = (200 x 60)/250
=> x = 48.

questions.question: In a certain time, a sum becomes 3 times at the rate of 5% per annum. At what rate of interest the same sum becomes 6 times in same duration?
questions.examples:
Example 1:
A sum of money at simple interest amounts to Rs. 815 in 3 years and to Rs. 854 in 4 years. The sum is:
A.
Rs. 650 B.
Rs. 690
C.
Rs. 698 D.
Rs. 700
Solution:
S.I. for 1 year = Rs. (854 - 815) = Rs. 39.
S.I. for 3 years = Rs.(39 x 3) = Rs. 117.
Principal = Rs. (815 - 117) = Rs. 698.

Example 2:
How much time will it take for an amount of Rs. 450 to yield Rs. 81 as interest at 4.5% per annum of simple interest?
A.
3.5 years B.
4 years
C.
4.5 years D.
5 years
Solution:
Time =(100 x 81)/(450 x 4.5) years = 4 years.
